On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at 6:06 AM, Alexander Johannesen
<alexander.johannesen@=
gmail.com> wrote:
> Hola,
>
> "Mike Kelly" <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
=
>> There are also server and client perspectives of the
>> interaction whic=
h *do* include these semantics - *established for a
>> URI by the server an=
d shared with the client via some hypertext
>> control*.
>
> Yes, but you a=
re the one who has decided well in advance that there is some
> specific se=
mantics required for this, something that is missing from REST
> itself and=
 the generic interface.

I don't think I did, I've just been trying to make=
 the point that you
just agreed with - which is that POST requests to diffe=
rent resources
do carry different semantics (determined by a hypertext appl=
ication).
Not from a network perspective (i.e. visibility), but from the cl=
ient
and server persepctive.

There's nothing wrong with that, it doesn't u=
ndermine HTTP or REST.
Hypertext is definitely a concern of REST, which is =
why 'hypertext as
the engine of application state' appears in its definitio=
n. I'm pretty
sure Roy has stated a couple of times that hypertext should'v=
e been
fleshed out in his dissertation but never made it because of time
co=
nstraints i.e. not because it 'hypertext is a layer above REST'.

>
>> One =
of the major issues I have with the RDF model is that it's
>> objective see=
ms to be to make every resource a possible 'starting
>> point' - i.e. it tr=
ies to provide a model for 'bootstrapping' a
>> machine client into a conte=
xt for any 'generic' resource on the web.
>
> Oh, don't get me wrong; I hat=
e RDF myself, a bunch of sissy triplets
> (triplets! Hah!) and anonymous no=
des trying to act all-encompassing and
> shareable, but with deep fundament=
al problems (persistent identifiers, and
> the aboutness of resources) ... =
:)
>
> However. RDF's heart is in the right place; ontology. And it is thro=
ugh a
> separate ontology you get your semantics.
>

Don't really mind what=
 we call it; as long as it is capable of
presenting a succinct, coherent, h=
uman-readable description of the
various ways a hypertext application can b=
e traversed.

not very fond 'ontology' though because the word stinks a bit=
 of
esotericism, and I prefer to think and talk about hypertext
application=
s in terms of happening rather than being anyway.

>> We don't have this in=
 REST, instead we have a limited set of entry
>> points and from then on di=
scovery/traversal of an application at run
>> time. This means there's a to=
nne of features (read: bloat) and
>> assumptions that are inherent to imple=
mentations like RDFa which, from
>> a REST pov, are at best distracting and=
 at worst actually corrosive to
>> the kinds of behaviours we are trying to=
 invoke when designing RESTful
>> hypertext applications.
>
> Hmm, big word=
s. Sure, the HTTP payload can be vexing, but far from hard to
> solve (cach=
ing, being a big one) using a multitude of ways; cached maps,
> cached reso=
urce mapping, cached vocabulary mappings, cached result-sets (of
> generics=
), and so on.
>
> I tend to say; create a crap HTTP client, and you'll get =
a crap HTTP system.
> There is no need to create a crap HTTP client.
>

The=
 problem I have with this advice is that in a distributed context
(e.g. a b=
ig SaaS API) the clients will be not be written by me,
they'll be written b=
y other people with their own (crappy) opinions
and (crappy) technology sta=
cks.

The real art of designing a REST application is in coaxing/herding th=
e
clients you don't control into adopting behaviours which will afford
you =
the flexibility to evolve. In many cases this means an application
design t=
hat compromises on 'perfection' in order to lower the barrier
to all the st=
upid clients e.g. this is exactly the reason there are no
'forms' in HAL.

=
>> REST's perspective on semantics seems to be based on a relational
>> the=
ory (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relational_theory) whereas RDF's
>> persp=
ective seems to be based on more of an absolute theory
>> (http://en.wikipe=
dia.org/wiki/Absolute_theory). I believe this
>> difference =A0is at the ro=
ot of the apparent schism between REST and RDF
>> and I can't find a way to=
 reconcile this, so I avoid RDF.
>
> It now depends on what you mean by RDF=
; the model (triplets, namespaces,
> etc.), the RDF ontology, the RDFS, OWL=
 (any of the three levels), or some
> model that uses the RDF family model =
to create something else (possibly
> meta). I can map RDF to Topic Maps jus=
t dandy, and create full-blown frames
> theory graphs (named or otherwise) =
with cumulative histographical node
> hopping just fine, so for me there is=
 no limitation that RDF itself is a
> faulty model. (And, truth be told, I =
don't use an RDF inferencer, I use
> Topic Maps all the way down, including=
 plural persistent identification
> management and separation of concerns b=
etween ontology, meta-data and data)
> I don't shun RDF (or, more specifica=
lly, RDFa) as it's a well-known, often
> used (well, more these days) metho=
d of creating key-value pairs attached to
> an ontology, and so just map th=
ose to whatever you need it for. I seriously
> fear that bringing these kin=
ds of semantics anywhere near REST will be the
> end of all that is good on=
 the web.
>

Are these read/write applications or just read?

Do you have m=
any external clients to your application? Did any of them
have no experienc=
e with RDF before interacting with your application?
If so how did the 'on-=
boarding' process go for them wrt RDF?

Cheers,
Mike
